notes: First generation W201 (1982-1993). First compact Mercedes. 190E 2.3 features Cosworth-developed engine. Diesel 190D available. Pioneer of Mercedes compact sedan segment. Diesel requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W201 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation W124 (1984-1997). Replaced W123. Multiple diesel variants available including 300D turbodiesel. E-Class designation adopted in 1993. Diesel requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W124 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation W126 (1979-1991). Longest S-Class production run. SEC coupe variant available. 560SEL features 5.6L V8. Introduced aerodynamic design and improved fuel efficiency. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W126 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation R107 (1971-1989). Longest SL production run at 18 years. 560SL features 5.6L V8. Removable hardtop. Known for build quality and durability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz R107 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation C126 (1981-1991). Coupe variant of W126 S-Class. 500SEC and 560SEC popular models. Pillarless hardtop design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W126 article, January 2025 revision.
